title: The Life of Henry the Eighth

scenes.location: London. An ante-chamber in the palace.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Good morrow, and well met. How have ye done Since last we saw in France?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: I thank your Grace, Healthful, and ever since a fresh admirer Of what I saw there.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: An untimely ague Stayed me a prisoner in my chamber when Those suns of glory, those two lights of men, Met in the vale of Andren.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: 'Twixt Guynes and Arde. I was then present, saw them salute on horseback, Beheld them when they lighted, how they clung In their embracement, as they grew together- Which had they, what four throned ones could have weighed Such a compounded one?

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: All the whole time I was my chamber's prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Then you lost The view of earthly glory. Men might say, Till this time pomp was single, but now married To one above itself. Each following day Became the next day's master, till the last Made former wonders its. Today the French, All clinquant, all in gold, like heathen gods, Shone down the English; and tomorrow, they Made Britain India: every man that stood Showed like a mine. Their dwarfish pages were As cherubins, all gilt. The madams too, Not used to toil, did almost sweat to bear The pride upon them, that their very labour Was to them as a painting. Now this masque Was cried incomparable; and th' ensuing night Made it a fool and beggar. The two kings, Equal in lustre, were now best, now worst, As presence did present them: him in eye, Still him in praise; and being present both, 'Twas said they saw but one, and no discerner Durst wag his tongue in censure. When these suns- For so they phrase 'em-by their heralds challenged The noble spirits to arms, they did perform Beyond thought's compass, that former fabulous story, Being now seen possible enough, got credit, That Bevis was believed.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: O, you go far.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: As I belong to worship and affect In honour honesty, the tract of everything Would by a good discourser lose some life, Which action's self was tongue to. All was royal; To the disposing of it nought rebelled; Order gave each thing view; the office did Distinctly his full function.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Who did guide, I mean, who set the body and the limbs Of this great sport together, as you guess?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: One, certes, that promises no element In such a business.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I pray you who, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: All this was ordered by the good discretion Of the right reverend Cardinal of York.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: The devil speed him! No man's pie is freed From his ambitious finger. What had he To do in these fierce vanities? I wonder That such a keech can with his very bulk Take up the rays o' th' beneficial sun And keep it from the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Surely, sir, There's in him stuff that puts him to these ends; For, being not propped by ancestry, whose grace Chalks successors their way, nor called upon For high feats done to th' crown; neither allied To eminent assistants, but spider-like, Out of his self-drawing web, he gives us note The force of his own merit makes his way A gift that heaven gives for him, which buys A place next to the King.

dialogues.speaker: Abergavenny
dialogues.line: I cannot tell What heaven hath given him-let some graver eye Pierce into that-but I can see his pride Peep through each part of him. Whence has he that? If not from hell, the devil is a niggard, Or has given all before, and he begins A new hell in himself.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why the devil, Upon this French going-out, took he upon him, Without the privity o' th' King, t' appoint Who should attend on him? He makes up the file Of all the gentry, for the most part such To whom as great a charge as little honour He meant to lay upon; and his own letter, The honourable board of council out, Must fetch him in he papers.

dialogues.speaker: Abergavenny
dialogues.line: I do know Kinsmen of mine, three at the least, that have By this so sickened their estates that never They shall abound as formerly.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: O, many Have broke their backs with laying manors on 'em For this great journey. What did this vanity But minister communication of A most poor issue?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Grievingly I think The peace between the French and us not values The cost that did conclude it.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Every man, After the hideous storm that followed, was A thing inspired and, not consulting, broke Into a general prophecy, that this tempest, Dashing the garment of this peace, aboded The sudden breach on't.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Which is budded out, For France hath flawed the league, and hath attached Our merchants' goods at Bordeaux.

dialogues.speaker: Abergavenny
dialogues.line: Is it therefore Th' ambassador is silenced?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Marry, is't.

dialogues.speaker: Abergavenny
dialogues.line: A proper title of a peace, and purchased At a superfluous rate!

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Why, all this business Our reverend Cardinal carried.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Like it your Grace, The state takes notice of the private difference Betwixt you and the Cardinal. I advise you- And take it from a heart that wishes towards you Honour and plenteous safety-that you read The Cardinal's malice and his potency Together; to consider further that What his high hatred would effect wants not A minister in his power. You know his nature, That he's revengeful, and I know his sword Hath a sharp edge; it's long, and 't may be said It reaches far, and where 'twill not extend, Thither he darts it. Bosom up my counsel; You'll find it wholesome. Lo, where comes that rock That I advise your shunning. and two Secretaries with papers. The Cardinal in his passage fixeth his eye on Buckingham, and Buckingham on him, both full of disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor, ha? Where's his examination?

dialogues.speaker: Secretary
dialogues.line: Here, so please you.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Is he in person ready?

dialogues.speaker: Secretary
dialogues.line: Ay, please your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Well, we shall then know more, and Buckingham Shall lessen this big look.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: This butcher's cur is venom-mouthed, and I Have not the power to muzzle him; therefore best Not wake him in his slumber. A beggar's book Outworths a noble's blood.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: What, are you chafed? Ask God for temp'rance. That's the appliance only Which your disease requires.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I read in 's looks Matter against me, and his eye reviled Me as his abject object. At this instant He bores me with some trick. He's gone to th' King. I'll follow, and outstare him.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Stay, my lord, And let your reason with your choler question What 'tis you go about. To climb steep hills Requires slow pace at first. Anger is like A full hot horse, who being allowed his way, Self-mettle tires him. Not a man in England Can advise me like you; be to yourself As you would to your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: I'll to the King, And from a mouth of honour quite cry down This Ipswich fellow's insolence, or proclaim There's difference in no persons.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Be advised. Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot That it do singe yourself. We may outrun By violent swiftness that which we run at, And lose by over-running. Know you not, The fire that mounts the liquor till 't run o'er, In seeming to augment it wastes it? Be advised. I say again, there is no English soul More stronger to direct you than yourself, If with the sap of reason you would quench, Or but allay the fire of passion.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Sir, I am thankful to you, and I'll go along By your prescription; but this top-proud fellow- Whom from the flow of gall I name not, but From sincere motions-by intelligence, And proofs as clear as founts in July when We see each grain of gravel, I do know To be corrupt and treasonous.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Say not "treasonous."

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: To th' King I'll say't, and make my vouch as strong As shore of rock. Attend. This holy fox, Or wolf, or both-for he is equal ravenous As he is subtle, and as prone to mischief As able to perform't, his mind and place Infecting one another, yea, reciprocally- Only to show his pomp as well in France As here at home, suggests the King our master To this last costly treaty, th' interview, That swallowed so much treasure, and like a glass Did break i' th' rinsing.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Faith, and so it did.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Pray give me favour, sir. This cunning Cardinal The articles o' th' combination drew As himself pleased; and they were ratified As he cried "Thus let be," to as much end As give a crutch to the dead. But our Count-Cardinal Has done this, and 'tis well, for worthy Wolsey, Who cannot err, he did it. Now this follows- Which, as I take it, is a kind of puppy To the old dam treason-Charles the Emperor, Under pretence to see the Queen his aunt- For 'twas indeed his colour, but he came To whisper Wolsey-here makes visitation. His fears were that the interview betwixt England and France might through their amity Breed him some prejudice, for from this league Peeped harms that menaced him. He privily Deals with our Cardinal, and, as I trow- Which I do well, for I am sure the Emperor Paid ere he promised, whereby his suit was granted Ere it was asked. But when the way was made And paved with gold, the Emperor thus desired That he would please to alter the King's course And break the foresaid peace. Let the King know, As soon he shall by me, that thus the Cardinal Does buy and sell his honour as he pleases And for his own advantage.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: I am sorry To hear this of him, and could wish he were Something mistaken in't.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: No, not a syllable. I do pronounce him in that very shape He shall appear in proof. Enter Brandon, a Sergeant-at-arms before him, and two or three of the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: Your office, sergeant: execute it.

dialogues.speaker: Sergeant
dialogues.line: Sir, My lord the Duke of Buckingham, and Earl Of Hereford, Stafford, and Northampton, I Arrest thee of high treason, in the name Of our most sovereign King.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Lo you, my lord, The net has fall'n upon me. I shall perish Under device and practice.

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: I am sorry To see you ta'en from liberty, to look on The business present. 'Tis his Highness' pleasure You shall to th' Tower.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: It will help nothing To plead mine innocence, for that dye is on me Which makes my whit'st part black. The will of heaven Be done in this and all things. I obey. O my Lord Abergavenny, fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: Nay, he must bear you company.  The King Is pleased you shall to th' Tower, till you know How he determines further.

dialogues.speaker: Abergavenny
dialogues.line: As the Duke said, The will of heaven be done, and the King's pleasure By me obeyed.

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: Here is warrant from The King t' attach Lord Montague, and the bodies Of the Duke's confessor, John de la Car, One Gilbert Peck, his chancellor-

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: So, so; These are the limbs o' th' plot. No more, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: A monk o' th' Chartreux.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: O, Nicholas Hopkins?

dialogues.speaker: Brandon
dialogues.line: He.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: My surveyor is false. The o'er-great Cardinal Hath showed him gold. My life is spanned already. I am the shadow of poor Buckingham, Whose figure even this instant cloud puts on By dark'ning my clear sun. My lord, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My life itself, and the best heart of it, Thanks you for this great care. I stood i' th' level Of a full-charged confederacy, and give thanks To you that choked it. Let be called before us That gentleman of Buckingham's; in person I'll hear his confessions justify, And point by point the treasons of his master He shall again relate. A noise within crying "Room for the Queen!" Enter  Queen Katherine, ushered by the Duke of Norfolk and the Duke of Suffolk. She kneels. The King riseth from his state, takes her up and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Nay, we must longer kneel; I am a suitor.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Arise, and take place by us. Half your suit Never name to us; you have half our power; The other moiety ere you ask is given. Repeat your will and take it.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Thank your Majesty. That you would love yourself, and in that love Not unconsidered leave your honour nor The dignity of your office, is the point Of my petition.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Lady mine, proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: I am solicited, not by a few, And those of true condition, that your subjects Are in great grievance. There have been commissions Sent down among 'em which hath flawed the heart Of all their loyalties; wherein, although, My good Lord Cardinal, they vent reproaches Most bitterly on you as putter-on Of these exactions, yet the King our master, Whose honour heaven shield from soil, even he escapes not Language unmannerly, yea, such which breaks The sides of loyalty, and almost appears In loud rebellion.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Not "almost appears," It doth appear; for, upon these taxations, The clothiers all, not able to maintain The many to them longing, have put off The spinsters, carders, fullers, weavers, who, Unfit for other life, compelled by hunger And lack of other means, in desperate manner Daring the event to th' teeth, are all in uproar, And danger serves among them.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Taxation? Wherein? And what taxation? My Lord Cardinal, You that are blamed for it alike with us, Know you of this taxation?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Please you, sir, I know but of a single part in aught Pertains to th' state, and front but in that file Where others tell steps with me.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: No, my lord? You know no more than others? But you frame Things that are known alike, which are not wholesome To those which would not know them, and yet must Perforce be their acquaintance. These exactions Whereof my sovereign would have note, they are Most pestilent to the hearing, and to bear 'em, The back is sacrifice to the load. They say They are devised by you, or else you suffer Too hard an exclamation.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Still exaction! The nature of it? In what kind, let's know, Is this exaction?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: I am much too venturous In tempting of your patience, but am boldened Under your promised pardon. The subjects' grief Comes through commissions, which compels from each The sixth part of his substance, to be levied Without delay; and the pretence for this Is named your wars in France. This makes bold mouths. Tongues spit their duties out, and cold hearts freeze Allegiance in them. Their curses now Live where their prayers did; and it's come to pass This tractable obedience is a slave To each incensed will. I would your Highness Would give it quick consideration, for There is no primer business.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: By my life, This is against our pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: And for me, I have no further gone in this than by A single voice, and that not passed me but By learned approbation of the judges. If I am Traduced by ignorant tongues, which neither know My faculties nor person, yet will be The chronicles of my doing, let me say 'Tis but the fate of place, and the rough brake That virtue must go through. We must not stint Our necessary actions in the fear To cope malicious censurers, which ever, As ravenous fishes, do a vessel follow That is new-trimmed, but benefit no further Than vainly longing. What we oft do best, By sick interpreters, once weak ones, is Not ours or not allowed; what worst, as oft, Hitting a grosser quality, is cried up For our best act. If we shall stand still In fear our motion will be mocked or carped at, We should take root here where we sit, Or sit state-statues only.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Things done well, And with a care, exempt themselves from fear; Things done without example, in their issue Are to be feared. Have you a precedent Of this commission? I believe, not any. We must not rend our subjects from our laws And stick them in our will. Sixth part of each? A trembling contribution! Why, we take From every tree lop, bark, and part o' t' timber, And though we leave it with a root, thus hacked, The air will drink the sap. To every county Where this is questioned send our letters with Free pardon to each man that has denied The force of this commission. Pray, look to't; I put it to your care.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: A word with you. Let there be letters writ to every shire Of the King's grace and pardon. The grieved commons Hardly conceive of me. Let it be noised That through our intercession this revokement And pardon comes. I shall anon advise you Further in the proceeding.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: I am sorry that the Duke of Buckingham Is run in your displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: It grieves many. The gentleman is learned and a most rare speaker; To nature none more bound; his training such That he may furnish and instruct great teachers And never seek for aid out of himself. Yet see, When these so noble benefits shall prove Not well disposed, the mind growing once corrupt, They turn to vicious forms, ten times more ugly Than ever they were fair. This man so complete, Who was enrolled 'mongst wonders, and when we, Almost with ravished list'ning, could not find His hour of speech a minute-he, my lady, Hath into monstrous habits put the graces That once were his, and is become as black As if besmeared in hell. Sit by us. You shall hear- This was his gentleman in trust-of him Things to strike honour sad. Bid him recount The fore-recited practices, whereof We cannot feel too little, hear too much.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Stand forth, and with bold spirit relate what you, Most like a careful subject, have collected Out of the Duke of Buckingham.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Speak freely.

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: First, it was usual with him-every day It would infect his speech-that if the King Should without issue die, he'll carry it so To make the sceptre his. These very words I've heard him utter to his son-in-law, Lord Abergavenny; to whom by oath he menaced Revenge upon the Cardinal.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Please your Highness, note This dangerous conception in this point, Not friended by his wish to your high person His will is most malignant, and it stretches Beyond you to your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: My learned Lord Cardinal, Deliver all with charity.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Speak on. How grounded he his title to the crown? Upon our fail? To this point hast thou heard him At any time speak aught?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: He was brought to this By a vain prophecy of Nicholas Henton.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What was that Henton?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: Sir, a Chartreux friar, His confessor, who fed him every minute With words of sovereignty.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: How know'st thou this?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: Not long before your Highness sped to France, The Duke being at the Rose, within the parish Saint Laurence Poultney, did of me demand What was the speech among the Londoners Concerning the French journey. I replied, Men fear the French would prove perfidious, To the King's danger. Presently the Duke Said 'twas the fear indeed, and that he doubted 'Twould prove the verity of certain words Spoke by a holy monk, "that oft," says he, "Hath sent to me, wishing me to permit John de la Car, my chaplain, a choice hour To hear from him a matter of some moment; Whom after under the confession's seal He solemnly had sworn that what he spoke My chaplain to no creature living but To me should utter, with demure confidence This pausingly ensued: ‘Neither the King nor's heirs, Tell you the Duke-shall prosper. Bid him strive To gain the love o' th' commonalty. The Duke Shall govern England.'"

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: If I know you well, You were the Duke's surveyor, and lost your office On the complaint o' th' tenants. Take good heed You charge not in your spleen a noble person And spoil your nobler soul. I say, take heed- Yes, heartily beseech you.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Let him on. Go forward.

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: On my soul, I'll speak but truth. I told my lord the Duke, by th' devil's illusions The monk might be deceived, and that 'twas dangerous For him to ruminate on this so far until It forged him some design, which, being believed, It was much like to do. He answered, "Tush, It can do me no damage," adding further That had the King in his last sickness failed, The Cardinal's and Sir Thomas Lovell's heads Should have gone off.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ha! What, so rank? Ah ha! There's mischief in this man. Canst thou say further?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: I can, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: Being at Greenwich, After your Highness had reproved the Duke About Sir William Bulmer-

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I remember Of such a time, being my sworn servant, The Duke retained him his. But on. What hence?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: "If," quoth he, "I for this had been committed," As to the Tower, I thought, "I would have played The part my father meant to act upon Th' usurper Richard who, being at Salisbury, Made suit to come in 's presence; which if granted, As he made semblance of his duty, would Have put his knife into him."

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: A giant traitor!

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Now, madam, may his Highness live in freedom, And this man out of prison?

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: God mend all.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: There's something more would out of thee. What sayst?

dialogues.speaker: Surveyor
dialogues.line: After "the Duke his father," with "the knife," He stretched him, and with one hand on his dagger, Another spread on 's breast, mounting his eyes, He did discharge a horrible oath, whose tenour Was, were he evil used, he would outgo His father by as much as a performance Does an irresolute purpose.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: There's his period, To sheathe his knife in us. He is attached. Call him to present trial. If he may Find mercy in the law, 'tis his; if none, Let him not seek 't of us. By day and night, He's traitor to th' height!

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Is't possible the spells of France should juggle Men into such strange mysteries?

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: New customs, Though they be never so ridiculous- Nay, let 'em be unmanly-yet are followed.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: As far as I see, all the good our English Have got by the late voyage is but merely A fit or two o' th' face; but they are shrewd ones, For when they hold 'em, you would swear directly Their very noses had been counsellors To Pepin or Clotharius, they keep state so.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: They have all new legs, and lame ones. One would take it, That never saw 'em pace before, the spavin Or springhalt reigned among 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Death! My lord, Their clothes are after such a pagan cut to't, That, sure, they've worn out Christendom. How now? What news, Sir Thomas Lovell?

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Faith, my lord, I hear of none but the new proclamation That's clapped upon the court gate.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: What is't for?

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: The reformation of our travelled gallants That fill the court with quarrels, talk, and tailors.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: I'm glad 'tis there. Now I would pray our monsieurs To think an English courtier may be wise And never see the Louvre.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: They must either, For so run the conditions, leave those remnants Of fool and feather that they got in France, With all their honourable points of ignorance Pertaining thereunto, as fights and fireworks, Abusing better men than they can be Out of a foreign wisdom, renouncing clean The faith they have in tennis and tall stockings, Short blistered breeches, and those types of travel, And understand again like honest men, Or pack to their old playfellows. There, I take it, They may, _cum privilegio, oui_ away The lag end of their lewdness and be laughed at.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: 'Tis time to give 'em physic, their diseases Are grown so catching.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: What a loss our ladies Will have of these trim vanities!

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, There will be woe indeed, lords. The sly whoresons Have got a speeding trick to lay down ladies. A French song and a fiddle has no fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: The devil fiddle 'em! I am glad they are going, For sure, there's no converting of 'em. Now An honest country lord, as I am, beaten A long time out of play, may bring his plainsong And have an hour of hearing, and, by 'r Lady, Held current music too.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Well said, Lord Sandys. Your colt's tooth is not cast yet.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: No, my lord, Nor shall not while I have a stump.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Sir Thomas, Whither were you a-going?

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: To the Cardinal's. Your lordship is a guest too.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: O, 'tis true. This night he makes a supper, and a great one, To many lords and ladies. There will be The beauty of this kingdom, I'll assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: That churchman bears a bounteous mind indeed, A hand as fruitful as the land that feeds us. His dews fall everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: No doubt he's noble; He had a black mouth that said other of him.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: He may, my lord; has wherewithal. In him Sparing would show a worse sin than ill doctrine. Men of his way should be most liberal; They are set here for examples.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: True, they are so, But few now give so great ones. My barge stays. Your lordship shall along. Come, good Sir Thomas, We shall be late else, which I would not be, For I was spoke to, with Sir Henry Guildford, This night to be comptrollers.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: I am your lordship's.

dialogues.speaker: Guildford
dialogues.line: Ladies, a general welcome from his Grace Salutes ye all. This night he dedicates To fair content and you. None here, he hopes, In all this noble bevy has brought with her One care abroad. He would have all as merry As, first, good company, good wine, good welcome Can make good people. O, my lord, you're tardy. The very thought of this fair company Clapped wings to me.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: You are young, Sir Harry Guildford.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: Sir Thomas Lovell, had the Cardinal But half my lay thoughts in him, some of these Should find a running banquet ere they rested, I think would better please 'em. By my life, They are a sweet society of fair ones.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: O, that your lordship were but now confessor To one or two of these!

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: I would I were. They should find easy penance.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Faith, how easy?

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: As easy as a down bed would afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Sweet ladies, will it please you sit? Sir Harry, Place you that side; I'll take the charge of this. His Grace is ent'ring. Nay, you must not freeze; Two women placed together makes cold weather. My Lord Sandys, you are one will keep 'em waking. Pray, sit between these ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: By my faith, And thank your lordship. By your leave, sweet ladies. If I chance to talk a little wild, forgive me; I had it from my father.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Was he mad, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: O, very mad, exceeding mad in love too; But he would bite none. Just as I do now, He would kiss you twenty with a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Well said, my lord. So, now you're fairly seated. gentlemen, The penance lies on you if these fair ladies Pass away frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: For my little cure, Let me alone. Hautboys. Enter Cardinal Wolsey and takes his state.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: You're welcome, my fair guests. That noble lady Or gentleman that is not freely merry Is not my friend. This, to confirm my welcome; And to you all, good health.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: Your Grace is noble. Let me have such a bowl may hold my thanks And save me so much talking.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: My Lord Sandys, I am beholding to you. Cheer your neighbours. Ladies, you are not merry. Gentlemen, Whose fault is this?

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: The red wine first must rise In their fair cheeks, my lord; then we shall have 'em Talk us to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: You are a merry gamester, My Lord Sandys.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: Yes, if I make my play. Here's to your ladyship; and pledge it, madam, For 'tis to such a thing-

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: You cannot show me.

dialogues.speaker: Sandys
dialogues.line: I told your Grace they would talk anon.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Look out there, some of ye.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: What warlike voice, And to what end, is this? Nay, ladies, fear not. By all the laws of war you're privileged.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: How now, what is't?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: A noble troop of strangers, For so they seem. They've left their barge and landed, And hither make, as great ambassadors From foreign princes.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Good Lord Chamberlain, Go, give 'em welcome-you can speak the French tongue- And pray receive 'em nobly, and conduct 'em Into our presence, where this heaven of beauty Shall shine at full upon them. Some attend him. You have now a broken banquet, but we'll mend it. A good digestion to you all; and once more I shower a welcome on ye. Welcome all! Hautboys. Enter King and others as masquers, habited like shepherds, ushered by the Lord Chamberlain. They pass directly before the Cardinal and gracefully salute him. A noble company! What are their pleasures?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Because they speak no English, thus they prayed To tell your Grace: that having heard by fame Of this so noble and so fair assembly This night to meet here, they could do no less, Out of the great respect they bear to beauty, But leave their flocks and, under your fair conduct, Crave leave to view these ladies and entreat An hour of revels with 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Say, Lord Chamberlain, They have done my poor house grace; for which I pay 'em A thousand thanks and pray 'em take their pleasures.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: The fairest hand I ever touched! O beauty, Till now I never knew thee.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: My lord!

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Your Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Pray tell 'em thus much from me: There should be one amongst 'em, by his person More worthy this place than myself, to whom, If I but knew him, with my love and duty I would surrender it.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: I will, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: What say they?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Such a one they all confess There is indeed, which they would have your Grace Find out, and he will take it.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Let me see, then. By all your good leaves, gentlemen; here I'll make My royal choice.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ye have found him, Cardinal. You hold a fair assembly; you do well, lord. You are a churchman, or I'll tell you, Cardinal, I should judge now unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: I am glad Your Grace is grown so pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My Lord Chamberlain, Prithee come hither. What fair lady's that?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: An't please your Grace, Sir Thomas Bullen's daughter, The Viscount Rochford, one of her Highness' women.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: By heaven, she is a dainty one. Sweetheart, I were unmannerly to take you out And not to kiss you. A health, gentlemen! Let it go round.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Sir Thomas Lovell, is the banquet ready I' th' privy chamber?

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: Yes, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Your Grace, I fear, with dancing is a little heated.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I fear, too much.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: There's fresher air, my lord, In the next chamber.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Lead in your ladies, every one. Sweet partner, I must not yet forsake you. Let's be merry, Good my Lord Cardinal, I have half a dozen healths To drink to these fair ladies, and a measure To lead 'em once again, and then let's dream Who's best in favour. Let the music knock it.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Whither away so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: O, God save ye. Even to the Hall, to hear what shall become Of the great Duke of Buckingham.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: I'll save you That labour, sir. All's now done but the ceremony Of bringing back the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Were you there?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Yes, indeed, was I.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Pray speak what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: You may guess quickly what.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Is he found guilty?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Yes, truly is he, and condemned upon't.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: I am sorry for't.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: So are a number more.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: But pray, how passed it?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: I'll tell you in a little. The great Duke Came to the bar, where to his accusations He pleaded still not guilty and alleged Many sharp reasons to defeat the law. The King's attorney on the contrary Urged on the examinations, proofs, confessions Of divers witnesses, which the Duke desired To have brought _viva voce_ to his face; At which appeared against him his surveyor, Sir Gilbert Peck his chancellor, and John Car, Confessor to him, with that devil monk, Hopkins, that made this mischief.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: That was he That fed him with his prophecies?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: The same. All these accused him strongly, which he fain Would have flung from him, but, indeed he could not. And so his peers, upon this evidence, Have found him guilty of high treason. Much He spoke, and learnedly, for life, but all Was either pitied in him or forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: After all this, how did he bear himself?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: When he was brought again to th' bar to hear His knell rung out, his judgement, he was stirred With such an agony, he sweat extremely And something spoke in choler, ill and hasty. But he fell to himself again, and sweetly In all the rest showed a most noble patience.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: I do not think he fears death.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Sure he does not; He never was so womanish. The cause He may a little grieve at.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Certainly The Cardinal is the end of this.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis likely, By all conjectures: first, Kildare's attainder, Then deputy of Ireland, who removed, Earl Surrey was sent thither, and in haste too, Lest he should help his father.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: That trick of state Was a deep envious one.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: At his return No doubt he will requite it. This is noted, And generally, whoever the King favours, The Cardinal instantly will find employment, And far enough from court too.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: All the commons Hate him perniciously and, o' my conscience, Wish him ten fathom deep. This duke as much They love and dote on, call him bounteous Buckingham, The mirror of all courtesy. with the edge towards him, Halberds on each side, accompanied with Sir Thomas Lovell, Sir Nicholas Vaux, Sir William Sandys and common people.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Stay there, sir, And see the noble ruined man you speak of.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Let's stand close and behold him.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: All good people, You that thus far have come to pity me, Hear what I say, and then go home and lose me. I have this day received a traitor's judgement, And by that name must die; yet heaven bear witness, And if I have a conscience, let it sink me, Even as the axe falls, if I be not faithful! The law I bear no malice for my death; 'T has done, upon the premises, but justice. But those that sought it I could wish more Christians. Be what they will, I heartily forgive 'em. Yet let 'em look they glory not in mischief, Nor build their evils on the graves of great men, For then my guiltless blood must cry against 'em. For further life in this world I ne'er hope, Nor will I sue, although the King have mercies More than I dare make faults. You few that loved me And dare be bold to weep for Buckingham, His noble friends and fellows, whom to leave Is only bitter to him, only dying, Go with me like good angels to my end, And as the long divorce of steel falls on me, Make of your prayers one sweet sacrifice, And lift my soul to heaven. Lead on, i' God's name.

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: I do beseech your Grace, for charity, If ever any malice in your heart Were hid against me, now to forgive me frankly.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Sir Thomas Lovell, I as free forgive you As I would be forgiven. I forgive all. There cannot be those numberless offences 'Gainst me that I cannot take peace with. No black envy Shall mark my grave. Commend me to his Grace, And if he speak of Buckingham, pray tell him You met him half in heaven. My vows and prayers Yet are the King's and, till my soul forsake, Shall cry for blessings on him. May he live Longer than I have time to tell his years; Ever beloved and loving may his rule be; And when old Time shall lead him to his end, Goodness and he fill up one monument!

dialogues.speaker: Lovell
dialogues.line: To th' waterside I must conduct your Grace, Then give my charge up to Sir Nicholas Vaux, Who undertakes you to your end.

dialogues.speaker: Vaux
dialogues.line: Prepare there! The Duke is coming. See the barge be ready, And fit it with such furniture as suits The greatness of his person.

dialogues.speaker: Buckingham
dialogues.line: Nay, Sir Nicholas, Let it alone. My state now will but mock me. When I came hither, I was Lord High Constable And Duke of Buckingham; now, poor Edward Bohun. Yet I am richer than my base accusers, That never knew what truth meant. I now seal it, And with that blood will make 'em one day groan for't. My noble father, Henry of Buckingham, Who first raised head against usurping Richard, Flying for succour to his servant Banister, Being distressed, was by that wretch betrayed, And, without trial, fell. God's peace be with him. Henry the Seventh succeeding, truly pitying My father's loss, like a most royal prince, Restored me to my honours and out of ruins Made my name once more noble. Now his son, Henry the Eighth, life, honour, name, and all That made me happy at one stroke has taken For ever from the world. I had my trial, And must needs say a noble one, which makes me A little happier than my wretched father. Yet thus far we are one in fortunes: both Fell by our servants, by those men we loved most- A most unnatural and faithless service. Heaven has an end in all; yet, you that hear me, This from a dying man receive as certain: Where you are liberal of your loves and counsels Be sure you be not loose; for those you make friends And give your hearts to, when they once perceive The least rub in your fortunes, fall away Like water from ye, never found again But where they mean to sink ye. All good people, Pray for me. I must now forsake ye. The last hour Of my long weary life is come upon me. Farewell. And when you would say something that is sad, Speak how I fell. I have done; and God forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: O, this is full of pity. Sir, it calls, I fear, too many curses on their heads That were the authors.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: If the Duke be guiltless, 'Tis full of woe. Yet I can give you inkling Of an ensuing evil, if it fall, Greater than this.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Good angels keep it from us! What may it be? You do not doubt my faith, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: This secret is so weighty, 'twill require A strong faith to conceal it.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Let me have it. I do not talk much.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: I am confident; You shall, sir. Did you not of late days hear A buzzing of a separation Between the King and Katherine?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Yes, but it held not; For when the King once heard it, out of anger He sent command to the Lord Mayor straight To stop the rumour and allay those tongues That durst disperse it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: But that slander, sir, Is found a truth now, for it grows again Fresher than e'er it was, and held for certain The King will venture at it. Either the Cardinal, Or some about him near, have, out of malice To the good Queen, possessed him with a scruple That will undo her. To confirm this too, Cardinal Campeius is arrived, and lately, As all think, for this business.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis the Cardinal; And merely to revenge him on the Emperor For not bestowing on him at his asking, The archbishopric of Toledo this is purposed.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: I think you have hit the mark. But is't not cruel That she should feel the smart of this? The Cardinal Will have his will, and she must fall.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: 'Tis woeful. We are too open here to argue this. Let's think in private more.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: _My lord, the horses your lordship sent for, with all the care had I saw well chosen, ridden, and furnished. They were young and handsome, and of the best breed in the north. When they were ready to set out for London, a man of my Lord Cardinal's, by commission and main power, took 'em from me, with this reason: his master would be served before a subject, if not before the King; which stopped our mouths, sir._ I fear he will indeed. Well, let him have them. He will have all, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Well met, my Lord Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Good day to both your Graces.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: How is the King employed?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: I left him private, Full of sad thoughts and troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: What's the cause?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: It seems the marriage with his brother's wife Has crept too near his conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: No, his conscience Has crept too near another lady.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: 'Tis so. This is the Cardinal's doing, the king-cardinal. That blind priest, like the eldest son of Fortune, Turns what he list. The King will know him one day.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Pray God he do! He'll never know himself else.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: How holily he works in all his business, And with what zeal! For, now he has cracked the league Between us and the Emperor, the Queen's great nephew, He dives into the King's soul and there scatters Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience, Fears and despairs-and all these for his marriage. And out of all these to restore the King, He counsels a divorce, a loss of her That like a jewel has hung twenty years About his neck, yet never lost her lustre; Of her that loves him with that excellence That angels love good men with; even of her That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls, Will bless the King. And is not this course pious?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Heaven keep me from such counsel! 'Tis most true: These news are everywhere, every tongue speaks 'em, And every true heart weeps for't. All that dare Look into these affairs see this main end, The French king's sister. Heaven will one day open The King's eyes, that so long have slept upon This bold bad man.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: And free us from his slavery.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: We had need pray, And heartily, for our deliverance, Or this imperious man will work us all From princes into pages. All men's honours Lie like one lump before him, to be fashioned Into what pitch he please.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: For me, my lords, I love him not, nor fear him; there's my creed. As I am made without him, so I'll stand, If the King please. His curses and his blessings Touch me alike, they're breath I not believe in. I knew him, and I know him; so I leave him To him that made him proud, the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Let's in, And with some other business put the King From these sad thoughts that work too much upon him. My lord, you'll bear us company?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Excuse me; The King has sent me otherwhere. Besides, You'll find a most unfit time to disturb him. Health to your lordships.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Thanks, my good Lord Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: How sad he looks! Sure, he is much afflicted.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Who's there? Ha?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: Pray God he be not angry.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Who's there, I say? How dare you thrust yourselves Into my private meditations? Who am I? Ha?

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: A gracious king that pardons all offences Malice ne'er meant. Our breach of duty this way Is business of estate, in which we come To know your royal pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ye are too bold. Go to; I'll make ye know your times of business. Is this an hour for temporal affairs, ha? Who's there? My good Lord Cardinal? O my Wolsey, The quiet of my wounded conscience, Thou art a cure fit for a king.  You're welcome, Most learned reverend sir, into our kingdom; Use us and it.  My good lord, have great care I be not found a talker.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Sir, you cannot. I would your Grace would give us but an hour Of private conference.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: We are busy. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: This priest has no pride in him?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Not to speak of. I would not be so sick, though, for his place. But this cannot continue.

dialogues.speaker: Norfolk
dialogues.line: If it do, I'll venture one have-at-him.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: I another.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Your Grace has given a precedent of wisdom Above all princes in committing freely Your scruple to the voice of Christendom. Who can be angry now? What envy reach you? The Spaniard, tied by blood and favour to her, Must now confess, if they have any goodness, The trial just and noble. All the clerks- I mean the learned ones in Christian kingdoms- Have their free voices. Rome, the nurse of judgement, Invited by your noble self, hath sent One general tongue unto us, this good man, This just and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius, Whom once more I present unto your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: And once more in mine arms I bid him welcome, And thank the holy conclave for their loves. They have sent me such a man I would have wished for.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Your Grace must needs deserve all strangers' loves, You are so noble. To your Highness' hand I tender my commission, by whose virtue, The court of Rome commanding, you, my Lord Cardinal of York, are joined with me their servant In the unpartial judging of this business.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Two equal men. The Queen shall be acquainted Forthwith for what you come. Where's Gardiner?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: I know your Majesty has always loved her So dear in heart not to deny her that A woman of less place might ask by law: Scholars allowed freely to argue for her.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Ay, and the best she shall have, and my favour To him that does best. God forbid else. Cardinal, Prithee call Gardiner to me, my new secretary. I find him a fit fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Give me your hand. Much joy and favour to you; You are the King's now.

dialogues.speaker: Gardiner
dialogues.line: But to be commanded For ever by your Grace, whose hand has raised me.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Come hither, Gardiner.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: My lord of York, was not one Doctor Pace In this man's place before him?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Yes, he was.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Was he not held a learned man?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Yes, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Believe me, there's an ill opinion spread, then Even of yourself, Lord Cardinal.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: How? Of me?

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: They will not stick to say you envied him And fearing he would rise-he was so virtuous- Kept him a foreign man still, which so grieved him That he ran mad and died.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Heav'n's peace be with him! That's Christian care enough. For living murmurers There's places of rebuke. He was a fool, For he would needs be virtuous. That good fellow, If I command him, follows my appointment. I will have none so near else. Learn this, brother: We live not to be griped by meaner persons.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Deliver this with modesty to th' Queen. The most convenient place that I can think of For such receipt of learning is Blackfriars. There ye shall meet about this weighty business. My Wolsey, see it furnished. O, my lord, Would it not grieve an able man to leave So sweet a bedfellow? But, conscience, conscience! O, 'tis a tender place, and I must leave her.

scenes.location: An ante-chamber of the Queen's apartments.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Not for that neither. Here's the pang that pinches: His Highness having lived so long with her, and she So good a lady that no tongue could ever Pronounce dishonour of her-by my life, She never knew harm-doing-O, now, after So many courses of the sun enthroned, Still growing in a majesty and pomp, the which To leave a thousandfold more bitter than 'Tis sweet at first t' acquire-after this process, To give her the avaunt, it is a pity Would move a monster.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Hearts of most hard temper Melt and lament for her.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: O, God's will! Much better She ne'er had known pomp; though't be temporal, Yet if that quarrel, Fortune, do divorce It from the bearer, 'tis a sufferance panging As soul and body's severing.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Alas, poor lady, She's a stranger now again.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: So much the more Must pity drop upon her. Verily, I swear, 'tis better to be lowly born And range with humble livers in content Than to be perked up in a glist'ring grief, And wear a golden sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Our content Is our best having.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: By my troth and maidenhead, I would not be a queen.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Beshrew me, I would, And venture maidenhead for't; and so would you, For all this spice of your hypocrisy. You, that have so fair parts of woman on you, Have too a woman's heart, which ever yet Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty; Which, to say sooth, are blessings; and which gifts, Saving your mincing, the capacity Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive, If you might please to stretch it.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Nay, good troth.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Yes, troth and troth. You would not be a queen?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: No, not for all the riches under heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: 'Tis strange. A threepence bowed would hire me, Old as I am, to queen it. But I pray you, What think you of a duchess? Have you limbs To bear that load of title?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: No, in truth.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Then you are weakly made. Pluck off a little. I would not be a young count in your way For more than blushing comes to. If your back Cannot vouchsafe this burden, 'tis too weak Ever to get a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: How you do talk! I swear again I would not be a queen For all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: In faith, for little England You'd venture an emballing. I myself Would for Caernarfonshire, although there longed No more to th' crown but that. Lo, who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Good morrow, ladies. What were't worth to know The secret of your conference?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: My good lord, Not your demand; it values not your asking. Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: It was a gentle business, and becoming The action of good women. There is hope All will be well.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Now, I pray God, amen!

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: You bear a gentle mind, and heavenly blessings Follow such creatures. That you may, fair lady, Perceive I speak sincerely, and high note's Ta'en of your many virtues, the King's Majesty Commends his good opinion of you, and Does purpose honour to you no less flowing Than Marchioness of Pembroke, to which title A thousand pound a year annual support Out of his grace he adds.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: I do not know What kind of my obedience I should tender. More than my all is nothing; nor my prayers Are not words duly hallowed, nor my wishes More worth than empty vanities; yet prayers and wishes Are all I can return. Beseech your lordship, Vouchsafe to speak my thanks and my obedience, As from a blushing handmaid, to his Highness, Whose health and royalty I pray for.

dialogues.speaker: Chamberlain
dialogues.line: Lady, I shall not fail t' approve the fair conceit The King hath of you.  I have perused her well. Beauty and honour in her are so mingled That they have caught the King; and who knows yet But from this lady may proceed a gem To lighten all this isle? I'll to the King, And say I spoke with you.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: My honoured lord.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: Why, this it is: see, see! I have been begging sixteen years in court, Am yet a courtier beggarly, nor could Come pat betwixt too early and too late For any suit of pounds; and you, O fate! A very fresh fish here-fie, fie, fie upon This compelled fortune!-have your mouth filled up Before you open it.

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: This is strange to me.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: How tastes it? Is it bitter? Forty pence, no. There was a lady once-'tis an old story- That would not be a queen, that would she not, For all the mud in Egypt. Have you heard it?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Come, you are pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: With your theme, I could O'ermount the lark. The Marchioness of Pembroke? A thousand pounds a year for pure respect? No other obligation? By my life, That promises more thousands; honour's train Is longer than his foreskirt. By this time I know your back will bear a duchess. Say, Are you not stronger than you were?

dialogues.speaker: Anne
dialogues.line: Good lady, Make yourself mirth with your particular fancy, And leave me out on't. Would I had no being If this salute my blood a jot. It faints me To think what follows. The Queen is comfortless, and we forgetful In our long absence. Pray do not deliver What here you've heard to her.

dialogues.speaker: Old Lady
dialogues.line: What do you think me?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Whilst our commission from Rome is read, Let silence be commanded.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: What's the need? It hath already publicly been read, And on all sides th' authority allowed; You may then spare that time.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Be't so. Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Scribe
dialogues.line: Say, "Henry King of England, come into the court."

dialogues.speaker: Crier
dialogues.line: Henry King of England, come into the court.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Scribe
dialogues.line: Say, "Katherine Queen of England, come into the court."

dialogues.speaker: Crier
dialogues.line: Katherine Queen of England, come into the court.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Sir, I desire you do me right and justice, And to bestow your pity on me; for I am a most poor woman and a stranger, Born out of your dominions, having here No judge indifferent nor no more assurance Of equal friendship and proceeding. Alas, sir, In what have I offended you? What cause Hath my behaviour given to your displeasure That thus you should proceed to put me off And take your good grace from me? Heaven witness I have been to you a true and humble wife, At all times to your will conformable, Ever in fear to kindle your dislike, Yea, subject to your countenance, glad or sorry As I saw it inclined. When was the hour I ever contradicted your desire, Or made it not mine too? Or which of your friends Have I not strove to love, although I knew He were mine enemy? What friend of mine That had to him derived your anger did I Continue in my liking? Nay, gave notice He was from thence discharged? Sir, call to mind That I have been your wife in this obedience Upward of twenty years, and have been blessed With many children by you. If, in the course And process of this time, you can report, And prove it too, against mine honour aught, My bond to wedlock, or my love and duty Against your sacred person, in God's name, Turn me away and let the foul'st contempt Shut door upon me, and so give me up To the sharp'st kind of justice. Please you, sir, The King your father was reputed for A prince most prudent, of an excellent And unmatched wit and judgement. Ferdinand, My father, King of Spain, was reckoned one The wisest prince that there had reigned by many A year before. It is not to be questioned That they had gathered a wise council to them Of every realm, that did debate this business, Who deemed our marriage lawful. Wherefore I humbly Beseech you, sir, to spare me till I may Be by my friends in Spain advised, whose counsel I will implore. If not, i' th' name of God, Your pleasure be fulfilled.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: You have here, lady, And of your choice, these reverend fathers, men Of singular integrity and learning, Yea, the elect o' th' land, who are assembled To plead your cause. It shall be therefore bootless That longer you desire the court, as well For your own quiet as to rectify What is unsettled in the King.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: His Grace Hath spoken well and justly. Therefore, madam, It's fit this royal session do proceed, And that without delay their arguments Be now produced and heard.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Lord Cardinal, To you I speak.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Your pleasure, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Sir, I am about to weep; but, thinking that We are a queen, or long have dreamed so, certain The daughter of a king, my drops of tears I'll turn to sparks of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Be patient yet.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: I will, when you are humble; nay, before, Or God will punish me. I do believe, Induced by potent circumstances, that You are mine enemy, and make my challenge You shall not be my judge; for it is you Have blown this coal betwixt my lord and me, Which God's dew quench! Therefore I say again, I utterly abhor, yea, from my soul Refuse you for my judge, whom, yet once more, I hold my most malicious foe and think not At all a friend to truth.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: I do profess You speak not like yourself, who ever yet Have stood to charity and displayed th' effects Of disposition gentle and of wisdom O'ertopping woman's power. Madam, you do me wrong. I have no spleen against you, nor injustice For you or any. How far I have proceeded, Or how far further shall, is warranted By a commission from the Consistory, Yea, the whole Consistory of Rome. You charge me That I have "blown this coal". I do deny it. The King is present. If it be known to him That I gainsay my deed, how may he wound, And worthily, my falsehood, yea, as much As you have done my truth. If he know That I am free of your report, he knows I am not of your wrong. Therefore in him It lies to cure me, and the cure is to Remove these thoughts from you, the which before His Highness shall speak in, I do beseech You, gracious madam, to unthink your speaking And to say so no more.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord, I am a simple woman, much too weak T' oppose your cunning. You're meek and humble-mouthed; You sign your place and calling, in full seeming, With meekness and humility; but your heart Is crammed with arrogancy, spleen, and pride. You have, by fortune and his Highness' favours, Gone slightly o'er low steps, and now are mounted Where powers are your retainers, and your words, Domestics to you, serve your will as 't please Yourself pronounce their office. I must tell you, You tender more your person's honour than Your high profession spiritual; that again I do refuse you for my judge; and here, Before you all, appeal unto the Pope, To bring my whole cause 'fore his Holiness, And to be judged by him.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: The Queen is obstinate, Stubborn to justice, apt to accuse it, and Disdainful to be tried by't. 'Tis not well. She's going away.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Call her again.

dialogues.speaker: Crier
dialogues.line: Katherine, Queen of England, come into the court.

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman Usher
dialogues.line: Madam, you are called back.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: What need you note it? Pray you keep your way. When you are called, return. Now, the Lord help! They vex me past my patience. Pray you, pass on. I will not tarry; no, nor ever more Upon this business my appearance make In any of their courts.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: Go thy ways, Kate. That man i' th' world who shall report he has A better wife, let him in naught be trusted, For speaking false in that. Thou art, alone- If thy rare qualities, sweet gentleness, Thy meekness saint-like, wife-like government, Obeying in commanding, and thy parts Sovereign and pious else, could speak thee out- The queen of earthly queens. She's noble born, And like her true nobility she has Carried herself towards me.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Most gracious sir, In humblest manner I require your Highness That it shall please you to declare, in hearing Of all these ears-for where I am robbed and bound, There must I be unloosed, although not there At once and fully satisfied-whether ever I Did broach this business to your Highness, or Laid any scruple in your way which might Induce you to the question on't? or ever Have to you, but with thanks to God for such A royal lady, spake one the least word that might Be to the prejudice of her present state, Or touch of her good person?

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: My Lord Cardinal, I do excuse you; yea, upon mine honour, I free you from't. You are not to be taught That you have many enemies that know not Why they are so, but, like to village curs, Bark when their fellows do. By some of these The Queen is put in anger. You're excused. But will you be more justified? You ever Have wished the sleeping of this business, never desired It to be stirred, but oft have hindered, oft, The passages made toward it. On my honour, I speak my good Lord Cardinal to this point And thus far clear him. Now, what moved me to't, I will be bold with time and your attention. Then mark th' inducement. Thus it came; give heed to't: My conscience first received a tenderness, Scruple, and prick on certain speeches uttered By th' Bishop of Bayonne, then French ambassador, Who had been hither sent on the debating A marriage 'twixt the Duke of Orleans and Our daughter Mary. I' th' progress of this business, Ere a determinate resolution, he, I mean the Bishop, did require a respite, Wherein he might the King his lord advertise Whether our daughter were legitimate, Respecting this our marriage with the dowager, Sometimes our brother's wife. This respite shook The bosom of my conscience, entered me, Yea, with a splitting power, and made to tremble The region of my breast; which forced such way That many mazed considerings did throng And pressed in with this caution. First, methought I stood not in the smile of heaven, who had Commanded nature that my lady's womb, If it conceived a male child by me, should Do no more offices of life to't than The grave does to th' dead; for her male issue Or died where they were made, or shortly after This world had aired them. Hence I took a thought This was a judgement on me, that my kingdom, Well worthy the best heir o' th' world, should not Be gladded in't by me. Then follows that I weighed the danger which my realms stood in By this my issue's fail, and that gave to me Many a groaning throe. Thus hulling in The wild sea of my conscience, I did steer Toward this remedy whereupon we are Now present here together. That's to say, I meant to rectify my conscience, which I then did feel full sick, and yet not well, By all the reverend fathers of the land And doctors learned. First I began in private With you, my Lord of Lincoln. You remember How under my oppression I did reek When I first moved you.

dialogues.speaker: Lincoln
dialogues.line: Very well, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I have spoke long. Be pleased yourself to say How far you satisfied me.

dialogues.speaker: Lincoln
dialogues.line: So please your Highness, The question did at first so stagger me, Bearing a state of mighty moment in't And consequence of dread, that I committed The daring'st counsel which I had to doubt And did entreat your Highness to this course Which you are running here.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I then moved you, My Lord of Canterbury, and got your leave To make this present summons. Unsolicited I left no reverend person in this court, But by particular consent proceeded Under your hands and seals. Therefore go on, For no dislike i' th' world against the person Of the good queen, but the sharp thorny points Of my alleged reasons, drives this forward. Prove but our marriage lawful, by my life And kingly dignity, we are contented To wear our mortal state to come with her, Katherine, our Queen, before the primest creature That's paragoned o' th' world.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: So please your Highness, The Queen being absent, 'tis a needful fitness That we adjourn this court till further day. Meanwhile must be an earnest motion Made to the Queen to call back her appeal She intends unto his Holiness.

dialogues.speaker: King
dialogues.line: I may perceive These cardinals trifle with me. I abhor This dilatory sloth and tricks of Rome. My learned and well-beloved servant, Cranmer, Prithee return. With thy approach, I know, My comfort comes along.-Break up the court! I say, set on.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Take thy lute, wench. My soul grows sad with troubles. Sing, and disperse 'em, if thou canst. Leave working.

dialogues.speaker: Woman
dialogues.line: Orpheus with his lute made trees And the mountain tops that freeze Bow themselves when he did sing. To his music plants and flowers Ever sprung, as sun and showers There had made a lasting spring. Everything that heard him play, Even the billows of the sea, Hung their heads and then lay by. In sweet music is such art, Killing care and grief of heart Fall asleep or, hearing, die.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: How now?

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: An't please your Grace, the two great Cardinals Wait in the presence.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Would they speak with me?

dialogues.speaker: Gentleman
dialogues.line: They willed me say so, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Pray their Graces To come near. What can be their business With me, a poor weak woman, fallen from favour? I do not like their coming. Now I think on't, They should be good men, their affairs as righteous. But all hoods make not monks.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Peace to your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Your Graces find me here part of housewife; I would be all, against the worst may happen. What are your pleasures with me, reverend lords?

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: May it please you, noble madam, to withdraw Into your private chamber, we shall give you The full cause of our coming.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Speak it here. There's nothing I have done yet, o' my conscience, Deserves a corner. Would all other women Could speak this with as free a soul as I do! My lords, I care not, so much I am happy Above a number, if my actions Were tried by every tongue, every eye saw 'em, Envy and base opinion set against 'em, I know my life so even. If your business Seek me out, and that way I am wife in, Out with it boldly. Truth loves open dealing.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: _Tanta est erga te mentis integritas, regina serenissima_-

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: O, good my lord, no Latin. I am not such a truant since my coming As not to know the language I have lived in. A strange tongue makes my cause more strange, suspicious. Pray speak in English. Here are some will thank you, If you speak truth, for their poor mistress' sake. Believe me, she has had much wrong. Lord Cardinal, The willing'st sin I ever yet committed May be absolved in English.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Noble lady, I am sorry my integrity should breed- And service to his Majesty and you- So deep suspicion, where all faith was meant. We come not by the way of accusation, To taint that honour every good tongue blesses, Nor to betray you any way to sorrow- You have too much, good lady-but to know How you stand minded in the weighty difference Between the King and you, and to deliver, Like free and honest men, our just opinions And comforts to your cause.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Most honoured madam, My Lord of York, out of his noble nature, Zeal, and obedience he still bore your Grace, Forgetting, like a good man, your late censure Both of his truth and him-which was too far- Offers, as I do, in a sign of peace, His service and his counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: To betray me. My lords, I thank you both for your good wills. Ye speak like honest men; pray God ye prove so. But how to make ye suddenly an answer In such a point of weight, so near mine honour- More near my life, I fear-with my weak wit, And to such men of gravity and learning, In truth I know not. I was set at work Among my maids, full little, God knows, looking Either for such men or such business. For her sake that I have been-for I feel The last fit of my greatness-good your Graces, Let me have time and counsel for my cause. Alas, I am a woman friendless, hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Madam, you wrong the King's love with these fears; Your hopes and friends are infinite.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: In England But little for my profit. Can you think, lords, That any Englishman dare give me counsel? Or be a known friend, 'gainst his Highness' pleasure, Though he be grown so desperate to be honest, And live a subject? Nay, forsooth, my friends, They that much weigh out my afflictions, They that my trust must grow to, live not here. They are, as all my other comforts, far hence In mine own country, lords.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: I would your Grace Would leave your griefs and take my counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: How, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Put your main cause into the King's protection. He's loving and most gracious. 'Twill be much Both for your honour better and your cause, For if the trial of the law o'ertake ye, You'll part away disgraced.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: He tells you rightly.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Ye tell me what ye wish for both: my ruin. Is this your Christian counsel? Out upon ye! Heaven is above all yet; there sits a judge That no king can corrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Your rage mistakes us.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: The more shame for ye! Holy men I thought ye, Upon my soul, two reverend cardinal virtues; But cardinal sins and hollow hearts I fear ye. Mend 'em, for shame, my lords. Is this your comfort, The cordial that ye bring a wretched lady, A woman lost among ye, laughed at, scorned? I will not wish ye half my miseries; I have more charity. But say I warned ye. Take heed, for heaven's sake, take heed, lest at once The burden of my sorrows fall upon ye.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Madam, this is a mere distraction. You turn the good we offer into envy.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Ye turn me into nothing. Woe upon ye And all such false professors! Would you have me- If you have any justice, any pity, If ye be anything but churchmen's habits- Put my sick cause into his hands that hates me? Alas, 'has banished me his bed already, His love, too, long ago. I am old, my lords, And all the fellowship I hold now with him Is only my obedience. What can happen To me above this wretchedness? All your studies Make me a curse like this.

dialogues.speaker: Campeius
dialogues.line: Your fears are worse.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Have I lived thus long-let me speak myself, Since virtue finds no friends-a wife, a true one- A woman, I dare say without vainglory, Never yet branded with suspicion- Have I with all my full affections Still met the King, loved him next heav'n, obeyed him, Been, out of fondness, superstitious to him, Almost forgot my prayers to content him, And am I thus rewarded? 'Tis not well, lords. Bring me a constant woman to her husband, One that ne'er dreamed a joy beyond his pleasure, And to that woman, when she has done most, Yet will I add an honour: a great patience.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Madam, you wander from the good we aim at.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: My lord, I dare not make myself so guilty To give up willingly that noble title Your master wed me to. Nothing but death Shall e'er divorce my dignities.

dialogues.speaker: Wolsey
dialogues.line: Pray hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Queen Katherine
dialogues.line: Would I had never trod this English earth Or felt the flatteries that grow upon it! Ye have angels' faces, but heaven knows your hearts. What will become of me now, wretched lady? I am the most unhappy woman living.  Alas, poor wenches, where are now your fortunes? Shipwrecked upon a kingdom where no pity, No friends, no hope, no kindred weep for me, Almost no grave allowed me, like the lily That once was mistress of the field and flourished, I'll hang my head and perish.
